contentrichtext.text: [[File:SitH - Rexall Bay Rum.jpg|thumb|This [[Rexall]] bay rum from the [[Prohibition in the United States|Prohibition]] era in the United States was labeled "for external use only," but with 58% [[grain alcohol]] it was often used as a legal means to obtain alcohol for drinking.<ref>''Stills in the Hills'', a 2012 exhibit at the White River Valley Museum, Auburn, Washington.</ref>]] '''Bay rum''' is the name of a [[Eau de Cologne|cologne]]/[[aftershave]] [[lotion]].<ref>http://www.stjohnbayrum.com/collections/st-johns-bay-rum-all-fragrances</ref> Other uses include as under-arm [[deodorant]] and as a [[fragrance]] for [[Shaving cream|shaving soap]], as well as a general [[astringent]]. [[File:Double distilled bay rum front.jpg|thumbnail|left|19th century trade card, showing bay rum from St. Thomas.]] It is a [[distillate]] that was originally made in [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Thomas]] "and probably other [[Caribbean|West Indian islands]]"<ref>John M. Maisch (Philadelphia), "On the Origin of Bay Rum", ''American Journal of Pharmacy'' '''33''' (1861:289).</ref> from [[rum]] and the leaves and/or berries of the West Indian bay tree, ''[[Pimenta racemosa]]''.<ref>Maisch identified the leaf in the herbarium at the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences, collected in [[St Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands|St Croix]], "by the late Dr, Griffith", which was identified as ''[[Myrcia|Myrcia acris]]'', now transferred to the genus ''[[Pimenta (genus)|Pimenta]]''; Maisch added "But it is very probable that various species are made use of for the same purpose."</ref> Other ingredients may be [[citrus]] and [[spice]] oils, the most common being [[Lime (fruit)|lime oil]], [[oil of cloves]]<ref>A drop of oil of cloves is added to two parts bay oil and one part pimento oil in one of two recipes for bay rum in "Practical notes and formulÃ¦", ''The Chemist & Druggist'', '''34''' (27 April 1889:576); the aromatics are steeped in alcohol and as a last step an equal part of "good rum" is added.</ref> and [[cinnamon]]. It was first made fashionable in [[New York City|New York]]<ref>Alice M. Coats, ''Garden Shrubs and their Histories'' (1964) 1992, ''s.v.'' "Laurus"</ref> and other American cities before it was available in Europe.<ref>"That it is little known in Europe may also be judged from the fact that it is not even mentioned in Piesse's Art of Perfumery" (Maisch 1861); George William Septimus Piesse, ''The Art of Perfumery'' (1857)</ref><ref>A recipe for bay rum from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy was included in ''The Pharmaceutical Journal'' (Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain) 23 February 1878:679</ref> Proprietary bay rum lotions are produced by labs in several West Indian republics, as well as American and European fragrance companies. The [[bay laurel]], the "bay leaves" in common culinary use, are from a completely unrelated species, ''Laurus nobilis'', and not the West Indian bay tree. Bay laurel can be used to produce a similar, although not identical, product. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Fragrances]] {{fashion-stub}}
